fields.description:
When initially starting a bfEBS Windows instance, the ephemeral disk which is assigned gets initialized by the system, so it's ready for use.  If the instance is then stopped and started again, the ephemeral comes up un-initialized.  This can be confusing for a user.

To reproduce:

(1) Start EBS-backed Windows instance
(2) Login and see ephemeral storage formatted and assigned a drive letter
(3) Stop EBS-backed Windows instance
(4) Start EBS-back Windows instance
(5) Login and use the "mmc" with the storage plugin to view disk details, you will be prompted to initialize the ephemeral.  Note its un-initialized state.
fields.summary: Starting a stopped bfEBS instance on Windows doesn't initialize ephemeral

comments.body:
Confirmed.

EBS-backed Instance was Windows 2003 R2 x64.
Harold, can you check in the registry under LOCAL_MACHINE.SOFTWARE.Eucalyptus Systems.Eucalyptus.FormatDrives ? It should be set to '1'. Just want to be sure before investigating further.

The basic sequence for formatting the ephemeral drive during boot occurs when the Eucalyptus windows service starts in the instance. It checks the registry to see if it should try to format drives and if that value is found and == 1, then it scans for uninitialized drives and starts formatting them. There are several logs kept during the operation so we should be able to determine if the format step is failing to run or is executing but encountering an error and terminating.
Hey Zach, I can confirm this value is set to "1" in the registry.
What version of Windows does this occur on ?

Hi John,

I've confirmed this on Server 2008.  Not tried other versions yet.

running kvm version kvm --version
QEMU PC emulator version 0.12.1 (qemu-kvm-0.12.1.2), Copyright (c) 2003-2008 

Produces an error :

 
[root@eucahost-51-177 windoz]# kvm -cdrom  en_server_install_disc_windows_storage_server_2008_r2_essentials_x64_dvd_658486.iso -drive if=scsi,file=windowsserver2008_debug_x64.kvm.img,boot=off

qemu: hardware error: Unknown device 'lsi53c895a' for bus 'PCI'
I would try leaving out if=scsi or try and change the HBA.

In creating the image, I defined an extra disk in my xml file:

<devices>
        <emulator>/usr/bin/kvm</emulator>
        <disk type='file'>
            <source file='/home2/windoz/w2k8/windowsserver2008r2_x64.kvm.img'/>
            <target dev='hda'/>
        </disk>
	 <disk type='file' device='disk'>
	     <source file='/home2/windoz/w2k8/Drive.img'/>
	     <target dev='vda' bus='virtio'/>
	</disk>


However "Drive.img" is not being seen under the Disk Mgr in windows.

This is before I even bundle the image.

I have been able to start and stop Windows ebs images that have 
volumes attached without being asked to initialize them .

Hi John,

Note these are not EBS volumes but the ephemeral disk space which is added as part of the machine type.

I have duplicated this behavior on Windows 2003x86 

This is the NC during the run state:

-drive file=/dev/sdc,if=none,id=drive-virtio-disk0,format=raw

-device virtio-blk-pci,scsi=off,bus=pci.0,addr=0x4,drive=drive-virtio-disk0,id=virtio-disk0,bootindex=1

The  ephemeral devices are destroyed when stopped , so reinitialization will be required on every restart.
I only see a disk manager prompt to initialize the disk on w2k3 and w2k8 if I manually navigate to disk storage view.
Sorry, I should have noted in the original report that in AWS this is not the behaviour.  The ephemeral space after a stop/start will NOT need to be re-initialized.

ephemeral devices are  volatile on stopping , so they need re-initialized on every start. 

    http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/InstanceStorage.html

Certainly the EBS instance store is volatile too, so there is no way to keep 
state between stops and starts.  I don't have a AWS account to verify.
Correct, but AWS does this automatically so a user doesn't have to worry about it. We do not re-initialize when we start up the instance again.

Euca provides a windows startup service that is suppose to (re) initialize the ephemeral device on every boot, which is essentially a format.  Are you proposing the windows start-up sequence formats the ephemeral device before hand instead ?

Hey John,

I think it just looks like it's not actually re-initializing the new ephemeral space on startup after a stop, so I don't think the method or point at which it does this needs to change, rather it needs to just work.

Fixed by 

$ git commit  -m "EUCA-3011, ephemeral disk lost on restart" EucaServiceLibrary.cs
[master 4214d9f] EUCA-3011, ephemeral disk lost on restart
 1 file changed, 16 insertions(+), 7 deletions(-)

Need to determine Windows Release policy since it is not within Linux build procedures.

$ git commit  -m "EUCA-3011, ephemeral disk lost on restart" EucaServiceLibrary.cs
[master 4214d9f] EUCA-3011, ephemeral disk lost on restart
 1 file changed, 16 insertions(+), 7 deletions(-)

Thanks for the work John, glad this is in for 3.2.

Btw, do you have a link to the commit on GitHub?
It is in a separate, private git repository for windows that gets built/released by itself. When I figure out finer details I'll let you know.
Thanks John, I'd love to get hold of the source for this :D
dealing with open source issues separately from the bug fix
issue is resolved, just looking for open source potential for this tool
any news on open sourciness of this?  I know there are some users who might want to work on this.  Thanks!
Asked Sang-Min to go ahead and open source the code.  Should be there shortly.
Awesome! thanks :D
Posted "beta" executables built from the github recently created for Lester to verify.

created a new iso :  10.101.1.11://home/jpdonnelly/work/defects/3011/windows-integration/EucaWindowsService1001.iso

Standard root password.

Unit test:  

  The issue corrects initializing ephemeral storage on Windows instance stop/start. 
  
  1. Apply this version to a image. 
  2. create a bfEBS instance from image. 
  3. Run brEBS instance. 

  4a. On initial boot, ensure d:\ ephemeral is present 
  4b. copy files to d:\ 
  4c. manually reboot instance : shutdown /r /t 0 /f 
  4d. files created in step 4b should be persistent on restart 

  5a. stop instance using euca-stop-instance 
  5b. start instance using euca-start-instance 
  5c. On  boot, ensure d:\ ephemeral is present, and empty
What is the official release vehicle for this?

Hey [~viglesias],

I tested this on eucalyptus-cloud-3.2.0-0.0.360.20121128git2203f627.el6.x86_64 and I dont see the behaviour anymore, looks like its fixed. But as you said not sure whats the release vehicle is
I have verified this in testing as well when creating windows image from ISO. What should the next step in the workflow be for this issue?
Fix verified using windows 7 x64 image from http://mirror.qa.eucalyptus-systems.com/windows_images/windows_euca3.2/kvm/ that has been updated with new tools

Hey Tony,

In your verification, did you verify if the disk size made available in ephemeral was correct?  Want to confirm EUCA-4274.
[~hspencer] I did not explicitly check the size when I verified this fix but I am pretty confident I remember seeing it as the correct size.  I will double check for you.
[~tony], [~hspencer], I think we need to open this one back up as the fix was never delivered in a *release* version of the WIT.
p.s. this applies to instance-store backed Windows on 3.3 too btw.
Reopening this as we'll need to test and make sure this is resolved in the Windows Integration Tool.  Currently scoped to release in the 3.4 release.

Quick update...
Verified with 2008 that ephemeral disks are initialized after stop/start. I could not test vmware at the moment due to EUCA-7415.
Windows may include some additional steps to bring the disk online and initialized. My previous round of testing showed the ephemeral disk, but it was not initialized.  I'm retesting a new 2012 image now and will update.
verified that ephemeral disk is initialized after stop-start.
